Instrument.name: Ultraviolet/Visible Camera for CLEM1
Instrument.description:
The Ultraviolet/Visible Camera (UVVIS) is an advanced imaging instrument designed for lunar mineral mapping. It features a catadioptic telescope with fused silica lenses focused on a metachrome-coated CCD imager. The instrument can operate across six selectable spectral bands controlled by a filter wheel and is optimized for capturing high-resolution images of the lunar surface.
The UVVIS records data in various integration times, depending on illumination conditions, achieving pixel resolutions of up to 100 meters at specific points and 400 meters at the poles. Calibration procedures were conducted both pre-launch and in-flight to ensure accurate radiometric and geometric measurements during the two-month lunar observation mission.
Operationally, the UVVIS camera utilizes a programmable integration time, adjustable gain settings, and offset modes to effectively capture images across different lunar latitudes. The instrument was capable of taking multiple images with varying exposure times to capture diverse surface features, ensuring proper signal-to-noise ratios and geometrical mapping needed for cartographic applications.
Specifications include a 288x384 pixel CCD sensor with a sensitivity range of 0.3 to 1.1 microns, operating in three modes and with a comprehensive filter system covering various wavelengths. The UVVIS plays a critical role in advancing our understanding of lunar geology through extensive imaging capabilities.
